title: Conic Sections
goals: Write and graph equations of circles in standard and general form
Write and graph equations of parabolas using focus and directrix
Write and graph equations of ellipses identifying foci, vertices, and axes
Write and graph equations of hyperbolas identifying asymptotes and foci
Identify conic sections from general second-degree equations
instructionalStrategy: All conic sections come from slicing a double cone at different angles. A circle is a horizontal slice, an ellipse is a tilted slice, a parabola is a slice parallel to the side, and a hyperbola cuts through both cones.

Every conic is defined by a DISTANCE relationship: circles (equal distance from center), parabolas (equal distance from focus and directrix), ellipses (sum of distances to foci is constant), hyperbolas (difference of distances to foci is constant).
Completing the square is the KEY algebraic skill for conics. If students can't complete the square fluently, they'll struggle with every conic section. Review this before diving in.
To identify a conic from Ax² + Bxy + Cy² + Dx + Ey + F = 0: look at A and C. Same sign, equal → circle. Same sign, unequal → ellipse. Opposite signs → hyperbola. One is zero → parabola.

scaffold.text:
**Circles:**

**Standard form:** (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r²
• Center: (h, k)
• Radius: r

To convert from general form (x² + y² + Dx + Ey + F = 0) to standard form, **complete the square** for both x and y.

**Parabolas (vertical axis):**
• Standard form: (x - h)² = 4p(y - k)
• Vertex: (h, k)
• Focus: (h, k + p)
• Directrix: y = k - p
• If p > 0, opens up; if p < 0, opens down

**Parabolas (horizontal axis):**
• Standard form: (y - k)² = 4p(x - h)
• Opens right if p > 0, left if p < 0

A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from the focus and directrix.
scaffold.initialPrompt: You already know parabolas from quadratic functions! The new piece is the focus and directrix. For y = x², rewrite as x² = 4p·y. What is p? Where is the focus?

scaffold.problem: Write the equation of a circle with center (-3, 2) and radius 5. Then convert x² + y² + 6x - 4y - 12 = 0 to standard form.
scaffold.explanation:
**Part 1: Writing the equation:**
Center (-3, 2), radius 5:
(x - (-3))² + (y - 2)² = 5²
**(x + 3)² + (y - 2)² = 25**

**Part 2: Converting to standard form:**
x² + y² + 6x - 4y - 12 = 0

Group x and y terms:
(x² + 6x) + (y² - 4y) = 12

Complete the square for each:
(x² + 6x + 9) + (y² - 4y + 4) = 12 + 9 + 4

**(x + 3)² + (y - 2)² = 25**

Center: (-3, 2), Radius: √25 = 5

Both equations describe the SAME circle!
scaffold.initialPrompt: Notice how completing the square in Part 2 gave us the same circle as Part 1. Can you identify the center and radius just by looking at the general form? Why is standard form so much more useful?

scaffold.text:
**Ellipses:**

Standard form (center at (h, k)):
• Horizontal major axis: **(x-h)²/a² + (y-k)²/b² = 1** where a > b
• Vertical major axis: **(x-h)²/b² + (y-k)²/a² = 1** where a > b

• **a** = semi-major axis (longer), **b** = semi-minor axis (shorter)
• **c** = distance from center to each focus, where **c² = a² - b²**
• Vertices are at distance a from center along major axis
• Co-vertices at distance b along minor axis

**Hyperbolas:**

Standard form:
• Horizontal: **(x-h)²/a² - (y-k)²/b² = 1** (opens left-right)
• Vertical: **(y-k)²/a² - (x-h)²/b² = 1** (opens up-down)

• **c² = a² + b²** (note: PLUS, not minus!)
• Asymptotes through center with slopes ±b/a (horizontal) or ±a/b (vertical)

Key difference: ellipses ADD fractions = 1, hyperbolas SUBTRACT fractions = 1.
scaffold.initialPrompt: For the ellipse x²/25 + y²/9 = 1, what are a and b? Which axis is the major axis? Where are the foci?

scaffold.problem: For the ellipse x²/16 + y²/9 = 1, find the vertices, co-vertices, and foci. Then for the hyperbola x²/9 - y²/4 = 1, find the vertices, foci, and asymptotes.
scaffold.explanation:
**Ellipse: x²/16 + y²/9 = 1**
a² = 16 → a = 4 (horizontal, since a² is under x²)
b² = 9 → b = 3
c² = a² - b² = 16 - 9 = 7 → c = √7

• Vertices: (±4, 0)
• Co-vertices: (0, ±3)
• Foci: (±√7, 0) ≈ (±2.65, 0)

**Hyperbola: x²/9 - y²/4 = 1**
a² = 9 → a = 3 (horizontal, x² is positive)
b² = 4 → b = 2
c² = a² + b² = 9 + 4 = 13 → c = √13

• Vertices: (±3, 0)
• Foci: (±√13, 0) ≈ (±3.61, 0)
• Asymptotes: y = ±(b/a)x = ±(2/3)x

Notice: ellipse foci are INSIDE the curve (c < a), hyperbola foci are OUTSIDE (c > a).
scaffold.initialPrompt: For the ellipse, why must c < a? Think about what the foci represent—they must be inside the ellipse. What happens to the ellipse shape as c gets closer to a?

problems.question: For the hyperbola y²/16 - x²/9 = 1, find the vertices, foci, and asymptotes.
Identify the conic: 4x² + 9y² - 16x + 18y - 11 = 0.
hints: Both x² and y² have same sign but different coefficients → ellipse.
Group and complete square: 4(x²-4x) + 9(y²+2y) = 11. → 4(x-2)² + 9(y+1)² = 36. Divide by 36.

scaffold.initialPrompt: For the first problem, since the vertices are on the y-axis, which variable gets the larger denominator?
